Introduction

Legg-CalvÃ©-Perthes disease (LCPD) is a hip disorder that primarily affects children.  It is due to an idiopathic osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) of the femoral head, which can cause progressive hip pain and deformation of the femoral head if not managed appropriately.

Pathophysiology



LCPD results from a disrupted blood supply to the femoral head, leading to subsequent avascular necrosis and deformity of the hip joint.  The cause of the disrupted blood supply in LCPD is unknown.

Risk factors



  • LCPD typically occurs between age 3 and 12, peaking between ages 5 and 7.
  • Male patients are affected more than female patients, with a male/female ratio of approximately 4:1.
  • Conditions that affect the blood supply to the hip (eg, thrombophilia, glucocorticoid use) are risk factors.
  • There is a genetic predisposition.  Approximately 10% of cases are familial.

Clinical presentation



LCPD typically has an insidious onset, and patients initially have dull hip pain that worsens with activity.  The hip pain can also present as a limp or referred knee pain.  Most cases of LCPD are unilateral, but approximately 10%-20% can be bilateral.



As the disease progresses, patients develop limited range of motion during internal rotation and abduction.  In addition, they may develop proximal thigh muscle atrophy (due to decreased use of the affected limb), resulting in Trendelenberg sign on examination (

figure 1
).  Limb length discrepancy may develop due to necrosis and slowed growth of the affected femoral head.

Differential diagnosis



  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis:  also presents with limp and insidious hip pain; however, patients are typically adolescent and obese.  In addition, x-ray shows posterior displacement of the femoral head.
  • Transient synovitis:  also presents with hip or knee pain and limp; however, symptoms typically develop after a viral infection and resolve within 4 weeks.
  • Infection:  bacterial arthritis typically presents acutely with fever and inability to bear weight as well as pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth of the joint.  Osteomyelitis typically affects the metaphyses of long bones (eg, humerus, femur) and classically presents with fever, point tenderness, and localized edema.
  • Malignancy:  primary bony malignancies can present with chronic and progressive pain in the long bones but typically reveal "onion skinning" (eg, Ewing sarcoma) or a sunburst pattern (eg, osteosarcoma) on x-ray.

Diagnostic evaluation



Imaging is helpful in the diagnosis of LCPD; however, a high index of suspicion is needed because radiographs are often normal at the initial presentation.  Other hip x-ray findings include:



  • Early disease:  joint space widening with a subchondral lucency of the femoral head (likely due to a subchondral fracture)
  • Advanced disease:  flattening and sclerosis of the femoral head (
    image 1
    ).


MRI and/or bone scan may be considered to evaluate the extent of disease, particularly if radiographs are not revealing.  MRI can demonstrate marrow changes suggestive of the diagnosis, and bone scan reveals decreased perfusion to the femoral head.

Management



The treatment of LCPD is aimed at maintaining the femoral head within the acetabulum.  This includes:



  • Rest and avoidance of weight-bearing activities to reduce stress on the affected hip
  • Splinting to support and protect the hip joint during healing


Surgical intervention (eg, femoral osteotomy) may be indicated in cases in which the femoral head is not well contained within the acetabulum.

Prognosis



The prognosis of LCPD depends on the age of onset, extent of involvement, and response to management.  Children age <8 tend to have a better prognosis, likely related to time for femoral remodeling.  If not managed appropriately or if treatment results in minimal improvement, patients can develop hip joint deformity, arthritis, and functional limitations later in life.
